content: Got this in reverse. I must say the trunk part is nonsense in that mode. I got it right relatively fast but it is such a random gambit which is exactly why I don't like these in reverse. Reverse shouldn't be about who's lucky to guess the random relation the creator thought of based on limited examples and no constraints but something that needs to be found.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Solved in 5 minutes in python, i liked it. good for all modes

Comment: Nice one :) only one i enjoyed today
I agree with other comments below. Please add shortest.

To prevent hard-coded solutions, test and validators need to be different.
Currently:
Test 1, Validator 5 have the same input (3)
Validator 1, Test 5 have the same input (2)
Test 2, Validator 2 have the same input (1)
Test 7, Validator 7 have the same input (20)

Typos:
Input: "inculded" -> "included"
Output: "symetric" -> "symmetric" 
Output: "drawed" -> "drawn" 
Output: "trunck" -> "trunk"
Love the addition of a bigger trunk for bigger trees.
After a typo pass, a better phrased explanation of the trunk's size & different cases for tests vs validators - this will be great.
Nice puzzle ! Why not include it in shortest mode as well ?
This is a great puzzle for reverse. The test cases are self-explanatory.
I think shortest instead of reverse
I don't like the reverse, because some langages have an advantage. Furthermore, in this challenge, there is no real short way to solve it.
Could you please give me a better phrased explanation example, my english is not good enough. Thanks !

Test cases updated. Each test and each validator is now unique.
I also changed the whole text, there should not be any typos problems.
Thanks for your feedback ;)
I do not agree with everyone, and don't want to include shortest, but it seems that everybody is asking for it so... shortest has been added.

I have been thinking about this. The test cases show the size of trunk part is 1/5 of the tree, by deduction. Let me explain:
- Test 1 and 2 : size = 3 and 1 -> trunk = 1
- Test 3 : size = 6 -> trunk = 2
Here, we only can deduce the trunk part is 1/3 or 1/4 or 1/5. But let's look further.

- Test 4 : size = 10 -> trunk = 2
The trunk part cannot be 1/3 and 1/4. So it's 1/5.

- Test 6 : size = 12 -> trunk = 3
- Test 7 : size = 20 -> trunk = 4
Thoses cases confirm 1/5 is the good solution.

Do you agree with my explanations ?
Anyway, I thank you for your feedback :)

Please don't get this wrong because I'm trying to indicate what's the problem with this in reverse. I'm also stating that in non-reverse modes it's perfectly valid.

You say that you get that the trunk is 1/5th of the incoming parameter (N) by deduction. The thing you forget is you deduced this by knowing the problem and the fact that you have preliminary knowledge that it is a proportion of N. But almost everyone playing clash who gets this problem as reverse hasn't. So they have to first guess it's proportionally related to N.

Also the result is actually ceiling(N / 5) and that's surprising. I have used the floor function thousands of times in my life but the ceil function only a few times. It's generally more natural to take the integer part of a decimal number as opposed to rounding it up. My first guess was floor(N / 4) + 1. But someone else might have associated to something else than division like some relationship to the Fibonacci series or whatever.

My problem was that the number of test cases showed that effort was put into the problem, probably several revisions and the top part is clearly very simple (logically) but the button part contains some trick. And that's when I get worried because I had seen so many bad examples in the past. Couple years ago I solved a problem where everyone got 80%, it had at least 3 different solutions, so I looked up what was the correct and it was some insane logic no human would have ever guessed. And it feels bad when you don't solve the problem but you guess it and do a leap of faith submit.

With that said, I don't think you should delete Reverse mode, and I don't know what can be changed, I just wanted to surface that most people solve problems without prior knowledge and that's what makes reverse really hard.

I see. I do not agree with you concerning the fact it's hard to deduce the trunk is a proportion of N. What else could be linked to the trunk size ? If it's not a constant, it's linked to a parameter. And the only parameter we have here, is the input (N).

Furthermore, I understand it's not easy to find the proportion score, but that's what make this puzzle interesting (according to some comments below).

I keep your note in mind, maybe you're not the only one having this feeling.

Thanks again for your feedback ;)
You changed the "Goal" text, but the typos I listed are in the "Input" and "Output" sections and haven't been changed.

Oh you're right... I should sleep more, I'm not focused enough. I correct it right away !
Thank you.

Adding different cases for test vs validators.
Thanks for the feedback :)

Here's a rewritten version, with extra clarifications for the player:

Draw a Pine tree that has a crown (part with branches) height of N rows,
and a visible tree trunk that is a fifth of the crown's height (rounded up).
The tree must be symmetric (without spaces to the right of the tree).
The crown is drawn with the * character, and grows wider on each new row.
The trunk is drawn with the | character, is one character wide, and is aligned with the tip of the tree.

If you're going to rewrite it yourself though, please consider adding the clarifications from above, as well as the following notes:
Typos: trunck -> trunk, inculded -> included, symetric -> symmetric, drawed -> drawn
"We need to build" -> "Draw" - it's a task for the player, there's no "we" here
"Christmas Tree" -> "Pine tree" - while both mostly refer to the same tree type - there's absolutely nothing festive in this task's tree's look
A huge thanks for your help ;)
I think you're confusing reverse and shortest modes: In SHORTEST mode, some languages (ruby, python) have an advantage. They don't have any advantage in reverse mode.
Oops ! Indeed, that's what I wanted to say :x

Thanks for your feedback !
I notice your comment ;)
You can save some characters if you don't  convert h to number, and remove Math.ceil() ;-)
